sp.l: That Women are like Tricks by Slight of Hand,
Which, to admire, we ſhould not underſtand.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: WHERE is Sir Sampſon? Did you not tell me, he would be here before me?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: He's at the great Glaſs in the Dining-Room, Madam, ſetting his Cravat and Wig.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How! I'm glad on't—if he has a Mind I ſhould like him, it's a ſign he likes me; and that's more than half my Deſign.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: I hear him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Leave me; and d'ye hear, if Valentine ſhould come or ſend, I am not to be ſpoken with.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: I have not been honour'd with the Commands of a fair Lady a great while—Odd, Madam, you have reviv'd me—Not ſince I was Five and Thirty.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why, you have no great reaſon to complain, Sir Sampſon, that is not long ago.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Zooks, but it is, Madam, a very great while, to a Man that admires a Fine Woman as much as I do.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You're an abſolute Courtier, Sir Sampſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Not at all, Madam: Odsbud you wrong me; I am not ſo old neither, to be a bare Courtier, only a Man of Words: Odd, I have warm Blood about me yet, and can ſerve a Lady any way—Come, come, let me tell you, you Women think a Man old too ſoon, Faith and Troth you do—Come, don't deſpiſe Fifty; odd Fifty, in a hale Conſtitution, is no ſuch contemptible Age.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Fifty a contemptible Age! Not at all, a very faſhionable Age, I think—I aſſure you, I know very conſiderable Beaus, that ſet a good Face upon Fifty; Fifty! I have ſeen Fifty in a Side-Box by Candle-light out-bloſſom Five and Twenty.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: O Pox, Outſides, Outſides; a pize take 'em, meer Outſides: Hang your Side-Box Beaus; no, I'm none of thoſe, none of your forc'd Trees, that pretend to Bloſſom in the Fall, and Bud when they ſhould bring forth Fruit: I am of a long liv'd Race, and inherit Vigour, none of my Family married 'till Fifty; yet they begot Sons and Daughters 'till Fourſcorce: I am of your Patriarchs, I, a Branch of one of your Antideluvian Families, Fellows that the Flood could not waſh away: Well, Madam, what are your Commands? Has any young Rogue affronted you, and ſhall I cut his Throat? or—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No, Sir Sampſon, I have no Quarrel upon my Hands—I have more occaſion for your Conduct than your Courage at this time. To tell you the Truth, I'm weary of living ſingle, and want a Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p:
Odsbud, and 'tis pity you ſhould—Odd, wou'd ſhe wou'd like me, then I ſhould hamper my young Rogues: Odd,
wou'd ſhe wou'd; Faith and Troth ſhe's deviliſh Handſom. [Aſide. Madam, you deſerve a good Husband, and 'twere a pity you ſhould be thrown away upon any of theſe young idle Rogues about the Town. Odd, there's ne'er a young Fellow worth hanging,—that is a very young Fellow—Pize on 'em, they never think beforehand of any thing;—And if they commit Matrimony, 'tis as they commit Murder, out of a Frolick: And are ready to hang themſelves, or to be hang'd by the Law, the next Morning:—Odſo, have a care, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Therefore I ask your Advice, Sir Sampſon: I have Fortune enough to make any Man eaſie that I can like; if there were ſuch a thing as a young agreeable Man, with a reaſonable Stock of good Nature and Senſe—For I would neither have an abſolute Wit, nor a Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Odd, you are hard to pleaſe, Madam; to find a young Fellow that is neither a Wit in his own Eye, nor a Fool in the Eye of the World, is a very hard Task. But, Faith and Troth, you ſpeak very diſcreetly; for I hate both a Wit and a Fool.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: She that marries a Fool, Sir Sampſon, commits the Reputation of her Honeſty or Underſtanding to the Cenſure of the World: And ſhe that marries a very witty Man, ſubmits both to the Severity and inſolent Conduct of her Husband. I ſhould like a Man of Wit for a Lover, becauſe I would have ſuch an one in my Power; but I would no more be his Wife than his Enemy. For his Malice is not a more terrible Conſequence of his Averſion, than his Jealouſie is of his Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: None of old Foreſight's Sybills ever utter'd ſuch a Truth. Odsbud, you have won my Heart: I hate a Wit; I had a Son that was ſpoil'd among 'em; a good hopeful Lad, 'till he learn'd to be a Wit—And might have riſen in the State—But, a Pox on't, his Wit run him out of his Mony, and now his Poverty has run him out of his Wits.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sir Sampſon, as your Friend, I muſt tell you, you are very much abus'd in that matter; he's no more mad than you are.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: How, Madam! Would I could prove it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I can tell you how that may be done—But it is a thing that would make me appear to be too much concern'd in your Affairs.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p:
Odsbud, I believe ſhe likes me— [Aſide.]—Ah, Madam, all my Affairs are ſcarce worthy to be laid at your Feet; and I wiſh, Madam, they ſtood in a better Poſture, that I might make a more becoming Offer to a Lady of your incomparable
Beauty and Merit.—If I had Peru in one Hand, and Mexico in t'other, and the Eaſtern Empire under my Feet, it would make me only a more glorious Victim to be offer'd at the Shrine of your Beauty.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir Sampſon, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Odd, Madam, I love you—And if you would take my Advice in a Husband—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir Sampſon. I ask'd your Advice for a Husband, and you are giving me your Conſent—I was indeed thinking to propoſe ſomething like it in Jeſt, to ſatisfie you about Valentine: For if a Match were ſeemingly carried on between you and me, it would oblige him to throw off his Diſguiſe of Madneſs, in apprehenſion of loſing me: For you know he has long pretended a Paſſion for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Gadzooks, a moſt ingenious Contrivance—If we were to go throw with it. But why muſt the Match only be ſeemingly carried on?—Odd, let it be a real Contract.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O fie, Sir Sampſon, what would the World ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Say, they would ſay you were a wiſe Woman, and I a happy Man. Odd, Madam, I'll love you as long as I live; and leave you a good Jointure when I die.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ay; but that is not in your Power, Sir Sampſon; for when Valentine confeſſes himſelf in his Senſes, he muſt make over his Inheritance to his younger Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Odd, you're cunning, a wary Baggage! Faith and Troth I like you the better—But, I warrant you, I have a Proviſo in the Obligation in Favour of my ſelf—Body o'me, I have a Trick to turn the Settlement upon the Iſſue Male of our two Bodies begotten. Odsbud, let us find Children, and I'll find an Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Will you? well, do you find the Eſtate, and leave the t'other to me—

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: O Rogue! But I'll truſt you. And will you conſent? Is it a Match then?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Let me conſult my Lawyer concerning this Obligation; and if I find what you propoſe practicable, I'll give you my Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p:
With all my Heart;—Come in with me, and I'll lend you the Bond,—You ſhall conſult your Lawyer, and I'll conſult a Parſon; Odzooks I'm a young Man: Odzooks I'm a young Man, and I'll make it appear—Odd, you're deviliſh Handſom: Faith and Troth you're very Handſom, and I'm very
Young, and very Luſty—Odsbud, Huſſy, you know how to chuſe, and ſo do I;—Odd, I think we are very well met;—Give me your Hand, Odd let me kiſs it; 'tis as warm and as ſoft—as what?—Odd, as t'other Hand—give me t'other Hand, and I'll mumble 'em, and kiſs 'em 'till they melt in my Mouth.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Hold, Sir Sampſon—You're profuſe of your Vigor before your time: You'll ſpend your Eſtate before you come to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: No, no, only give you a Rent-roll of my Poſſeſſions—Ah! Baggage—I warrant you; for little Sampſon: Odd, Sampſon's a very good Name for an able Fellow: Your Sampſons were ſtrong Dogs from the Beginning.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Have a care, and don't over-act your Part—If you remember, the ſtrongeſt Sampſon of your Name pull'd an old Houſe over his Head at laſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Huſſy?—Come, let's go then; Odd, I long to be pulling down too, come away—Odſo, here's ſome Body coming.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Is not that ſhe, gone out juſt now?

sp.speaker: Jere.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, ſhe's juſt going to the Place of Appointment. Ah, Sir, if you are not very faithful and cloſe in this Buſineſs, you'll certainly be the Death of a Perſon that has a moſt extraordinary Paſſion for your Honour's Service.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Ay, who's that?

sp.speaker: Jere.
sp.p: Even my unworthy ſelf, Sir—Sir, I have had an Appetite to be fed with your Commands a great while;—And now, Sir, my former Maſter having much troubled the Fountain of his Underſtanding, it is a very plauſible Occaſion for me to quench my Thirſt at the Spring of your Bounty—I thought I could not recommend my ſelf better to you, Sir, than by the delivery of a great Beauty and Fortune into your Arms, whom I have heard you ſigh for.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: I'll make thy Fortune; ſay no more—Thou art a pretty Fellow, and can'ſt carry a Meſſage to a Lady in a pretty ſoft kind of Phraſe, and with a good perſuading Accent.

sp.speaker: Jere.
sp.p: Sir, I have the Seeds of Rhetorick and Oratory in my Head—I have been at Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Ay; 'tis well enough for a Servant to be bred at an Univerſity: But the Education is a little too Pedantick for a Gentleman. I hope you are ſecret in your Nature, private, cloſe, ha?

sp.speaker: Jere.
sp.p: O Sir, for that, Sir, 'tis my chief Talent; I'm as ſecret as the Head of Nilus.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Hye? Who's he, tho'? A Privy-Counſellor?

sp.speaker: Jere.
sp.p: O Ignorance! [aſide.] A cunning Aegyptian, Sir, that with his Arms would over-run the Country, yet no body could ever find out his Head-Quarters.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Cloſe Dog! A good Whoremaſter, I warrant him—The Time draws nigh, Jeremy. Angelica will be veil'd like a Nun; and I muſt be hooded like a Friar; ha, Jeremy?

sp.speaker: Jere.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, hooded like a Hawk, to ſeize at firſt ſight upon the Quarry. It is the Whim of my Maſter's Madneſs to be ſo dreſs'd; and ſhe is ſo in Love with him, ſhe'll comply with any thing to pleaſe him. Poor Lady, I'm ſure ſhe'll have reaſon to pray for me, when ſhe finds what a happy Exchange ſhe has made, between a Madman and ſo Accompliſh'd a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Ay Faith, ſo ſhe will, Jeremy: You're a good Friend to her, poor Creature—I ſwear I do it hardly ſo much in Conſideration of my ſelf, as Compaſſion to her.

sp.speaker: Jere.
sp.p: 'Tis an Act of Charity, Sir, to ſave a fine Woman with Thirty Thouſand Pound, from throwing her ſelf away.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: So 'tis, faith—I might have ſav'd ſeveral others in my time; but I Gad I could never find in my Heart to Marry any body before.

sp.speaker: Jere.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'll go and tell her my Maſter's coming; and meet you in half a quarter of an Hour, with your Diſguiſe, at your own Lodgings. You muſt talk a little madly, ſhe won't diſtinguiſh the Tone of your Voice.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: No, no, let me alone for a Counterfeit—I'll be ready for you.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: O Mr. Tattle, are you here! I'm glad I have found you; I have been looking up and down for you like any thing, 'till I'm as tired as any thing in the World.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: O Pox how ſhall I get rid of this fooliſh Girl? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: O I have pure News, I can tell you pure News—I muſt not marry the Seaman now—my Father ſays ſo. Why won't you be my Husband? You ſay you love me, and you won't be my Huſband. And I know you may be my Husband now if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: O fie, Miſs: Who told you ſo, Child?

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: Why, my Father—I told him that you lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: O fie, Miſs; why did you do ſo? And who told you ſo, Child?

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: Who? Why you did; did not you?

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: O Pox, that was Yeſterday, Miſs; that was a great while ago, Child. I have been aſleep ſince; ſlept a whole Night, and did not ſo much as dream of the matter.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: Pſhaw, O but I dream'd that it was ſo tho'.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Ay, but your Father will tell you that Dreams come by Contraries, Child—O fie; what, we muſt not love one another now—Pſhaw, that would be a fooliſh thing indeed—Fie, fie, you are a Woman now, and muſt think of a new Man every Morning, and forget him every Night—No, no, to marry is to be a Child again, and play with the ſame Rattle always: O fie, Marrying is a paw thing.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: Well, but don't you love me as well as you did laſt Night then?

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: No, no, Child, you would not have me.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: No? Yes but I would tho'.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Pſhaw, but I tell you, you would not—You forget you're a Woman, and don't know your own Mind.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: But here's my Father, and he knows my Mind.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: O, Mr. Tattle, your Servant, you are a cloſe Man; but methinks your Love to my Daughter was a Secret I might have been truſted with,—Or had you a mind to try if I could diſcover it by my Art—hum, ha! I think there is ſomething in your Phyſiognomy, that has a Reſemblance of her; and the Girl is like me.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: And ſo you would infer, that you and I are alike—what does the old Prig mean? I'll banter him, and laugh at him, and leave him. [aſide.] I fancy you have a wrong Notion of Faces.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: How? What? A wrong Notion! How ſo?

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: In the way of Art: I have ſome taking Features, not obvious to Vulgar Eyes, that are Indications of a ſudden turn of good Fortune, in the Lottery of Wives; and Promiſe of great Beauty and great Fortune reſerv'd alone for me, by a private Intrigue of Deſtiny, kept ſecret from the piercing Eye of Perſpicuity; from all Aſtrologers, and the Stars themſelves.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: How! I will make it appear, that what you ſay is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your Pardon, I'm in haſte—

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: To be married, Sir, married.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Ay, but pray take me along with you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis to be done privately—I never make Confidents.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Well; but my Conſent I mean—You won't marry my Daughter without my Conſent?

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Who I, Sir? I'm an abſolute Stranger to you and your Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Hey day! What time of the Moon is this?

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Very true, Sir, and deſire to continue ſo. I have no more Love for your Daughter, than I have Likeneſs of you; and I have a Secret in my Heart, which you would be glad to know, and ſhan't know; and yet you ſhall know it too, and be ſorry for't afterwards. I'd have you to know, Sir, that I am as knowing as the Stars, and as ſecret as the Night. And I'm going to be married juſt now, yet did not know of it half an Hour ago; and the Lady ſtays for me, and does not know of it yet—There's a Myſtery for you,—I know you love to untie Difficulties—Or if you can't ſolve this, ſtay here a quarter of an Hour, and I'll come and explain it to you.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: O Father, why will you let him go? Won't you make him to be my Husband?

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Mercy on us, what do theſe Lunacies portend? Alas! he's mad, Child, ſtark wild.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: What, and muſt not I have e'er a Husband then? What, muſt I go to Bed to Nurſe again, and be a Child as long as ſhe's an Old Woman? Indeed but I won't: For now my Mind is ſet upon a Man, I will have a Man ſome way or other. Oh! methinks I'm ſick when I think of a Man; and if I can't have one, I would go to ſleep all my Life: For when I'm awake, it makes me wiſh and long, and I don't know for what—And I'd rather be always aſleep, than ſick with Thinking.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: O fearful! I think the Girl's influenc'd too,—Huſſie, you ſhall have a Rod.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.p: A Fiddle of a Rod, I'll have a Husband; and if you won't get me one, I'll get one for my ſelf: I'll marry our Robbin the Buttler, he ſays he loves me, and he's a Handſom Man, and ſhall be my Husband: I warrant he'll be my Husband and thank me too, for he told me ſo.

div.stage: Enter Scandal, Mrs. Foreſight, and Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Did he ſo—I'll diſpatch him for't preſently; Rogue! Oh, Nurſe, come hither.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: What is your Worſhip's Pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p:
Here take your Young Miſtreſs, and lock her up preſently,
'till farther Orders from me—Not a Word, Huſſie—Do what I bid you, no Reply, away. And bid Robbin make ready to give an Account of his Plate and Linnen, d'ye hear, begone when I bid you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: What's the matter, Husband?

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: 'Tis not convenient to tell you now—Mr. Scandal, Heav'n keep us all in our Senſes—I fear there is a contagious Frenzy abroad. How does Valentine?

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: O I hope he will do well again—I have a Meſſage from him to your Niece Angelica.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: I think ſhe has not return'd, ſince ſhe went abroad with Sir Sampſon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: Here's Mr. Benjamin, he can tell us if his Father be come home.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Who, Father? ay, he's come home with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: Why, what's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Matter! Why he's mad.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Mercy on us, I was afraid of this.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: And there's the Handſom Young Woman, ſhe, as they ſay, Brother Val. went mad for, ſhe's mad too, I think.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: O my poor Niece, my poor Niece, is ſhe gone too? Well, I ſhall run mad next.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: Well, but how mad? how d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Nay, I'll give you leave to gueſs—I'll undertake to make a Voyage to Antegoa—No, hold, I mayn't ſay ſo neither—But I'll ſail as far as Legorn, and back again, before you ſhall gueſs at the matter, and do nothing elſe; Meſs, you may take in all the Points of the Compaſs, and not hit right.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: Your Experiment will take up a little too much Time.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why then I'll tell you, There's a new Wedding upon the Stocks; and they two are a going to be married to rights.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why Father, and—the Young Woman. I can't hit of her Name.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: Angelica?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ay, the ſame.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: Sir Sampſon and Angelica, impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: That may be—but I'm ſure it is as I tell you.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: 'S'death it's a Jeſt, I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Look you, Friend, it's nothing to me, whether you believe
it or no. What I ſay is true; d'ye ſee, they are married, or juſt going to be married, I know not which.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Well, but they are hot mad, that is, not Lunatick?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I don't know what you may call Madneſs—But ſhe's mad for a Husband, and he's Horn-mad, I think, or they'd ne'er make a Match together—Here they come.

div.stage: Enter Sir Sampſon, Angelica, with Buckram.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Where is this old Soothſayer? This Uncle of mine Elect? A ha, Old Foreſight, Uncle Foreſight, wiſh me Joy, Uncle Foreſight, double Joy, both as Uncle and Aſtrologer; here's a Conjunction that was not foretold in all your Ephemeris—The brighteſt Star in the blue Firmament—is ſhot from above, in a Jelly of Love, and ſo forth; and I'm Lord of the Aſcendant. Odd, you're an Old Fellow, Foreſight; Uncle, I mean, a very Old Fellow, Uncle Foreſight; and yet you ſhall live to dance at my Wedding; Faith and Troth you ſhall. Odd, we'll have the Muſick of the Spheres for thee, Old Lilly, that we will, and thou ſhalt lead up a Dance in Via Lactea.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: I'm Thunder-ſtruck! You are not married to my Niece?

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Not abſolutely married, Uncle; but very near it, within a Kiſs of the matter, as you ſee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: 'Tis very true indeed, Uncle; I hope you'll be my Father, and give me.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: That he ſhall, or I'll burn his Globes—Body o'me, he ſhall be thy Father, I'll make him thy Father, and thou ſhalt make me a Father, and I'll make thee a Mother, and we'll beget Sons and Daughters enough to put the Weekly Bills out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: Death and Hell! Where's Valentine?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: This is ſo ſurprizing—

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: How! What does my Aunt ſay? Surprizing, Aunt? Not at all, for a young Couple to make a Match in Winter? Not at all—It's a Plot to undermine Cold Weather, and deſtroy that Uſurper of a Bed call'd a Warming-Pan.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear you have ſo much Fire in you, Sir Sampſon.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Meſs, I fear his Fire's little better than Tinder; may-hap it will only ſerve to light up a Match for ſome Body elſe. The Young Woman's a Handſom Young Woman, I can't deny it: But Father, if I might be your Pilot in this Caſe, you ſhould not marry her. It's juſt the ſame thing, as if ſo be you ſhould Sail ſo far as the Straights without Proviſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Who gave you Authority to ſpeak, Sirrah? To your Element, Fiſh, be mute, Fiſh, and to Sea, rule your Helm, Sirrah, don't direct me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Well, well, take you care of your own Helm, or you mayn't keep your new Veſſel ſteddy.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Why, you impudent Tarpawlin! Sirrah, do you bring your Fore-caſtle Jeſts upon your Father? But I ſhall be even with you, I won't give you a Groat. Mr. Buckram, is the Conveyance ſo worded, that nothing can poſſibly deſcend to this Scoundrel? I would not ſo much as have him have the Proſpect of an Eſtate; tho' there were no way to come to it, but by the North-Eaſt Paſſage.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Sir, it is drawn according to your Directions; there is not the leaſt Cranny of the Law unſtopp'd.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Lawyer, I believe there's many a Cranny and Leak unſtopp'd in your Conſcience—If ſo be that one had a Pump to your Boſom, I believe we ſhould diſcover a foul Hold. They ſay a Witch will ſail in a Sieve—But I believe the Devil would not venture abroad o'your Conſcience. And that's for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, Sirrah. How now, who's there?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O, Sir, the moſt unlucky Accident!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: O, the two moſt unfortunate poor Creatures in the World we are.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Bleſs us! How ſo?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Tattle and I, poor Mr. Tattle and I are—I can't ſpeak it out.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Nor I—But poor Mrs. Frail and I are—

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Married.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: Married! How?

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Suddenly—before we know where we were—that Villain Jeremy, by the help of Diſguiſes, trick'd us into one another.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Why, you told me juſt now, you went hence in haſte to be married.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: But I believe Mr. Tattle meant the Favour to me, I thank him.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: I did, as I hope to be ſav'd, Madam, my Intentions were good—But this is the moſt cruel thing, to marry one does not know how, nor why, nor wherefore—The Devil take me if ever I was ſo much concern'd at any thing in my Life.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: 'Tis very unhappy, if you don't care for one another.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: The leaſt in the World—That is for my Part, I ſpeak for my ſelf. Gad, I never had the leaſt thought of ſerious Kindneſs—I never lik'd any Body leſs in my Life. Poor Woman! Gad I'm ſorry for her too; for I have no reaſon to hate her neither; but I believe I ſhall lead her a damn'd ſort of a Life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fore.
sp.p: He's better than no Husband at all—tho' he's a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: to her.] Ay, ay, it's well it's no worſe—Nay, for my part I always deſpis'd Mr. Tattle of all things; nothing but his being my Husband could have made me like him leſs.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Look you there, I thought as much—Pox on't, I wiſh we could keep it ſecret, why I don't believe any of this Company would ſpeak of it.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: But, my Dear, that's impoſſible; the Parſon and that Rogue Jeremy will publiſh it.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Ay, my Dear, ſo they will, as you ſay.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O you'll agree very well in a little time; Cuſtom will make it eaſie to you.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: Eaſie! Pox on't, I don't believe I ſhall Sleep to Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Sleep Quotha! No, why you would not Sleep o'your Wedding Night? I'm an older Fellow than you, and don't mean to Sleep.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why there's another Match now, as tho'f a couple of Privateers were looking for a Prize, and ſhould fall foul of one another. I'm ſorry for the Young Man with all my Heart. Look you, Friend, if I may adviſe you, when ſhe's going, for that you muſt expect, I have Experience of her, when ſhe's going, let her go. For no Matrimony is tough enough to hold her, and if ſhe can't drag her Anchor along with her, ſhe'll break her Cable, I can tell you that. Who's here? the Madman?

div.stage: Enter Valentine dreſs'd, Scandal and Jeremy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, here's the Fool; and if occaſion be, I'll give it under my Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I'm come to acknowledge my Errors, and ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: What have you found your Senſes at laſt then? In good time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You were abus'd, Sir, I never was diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: How! Not Mad! Mr. Scandal?

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: No really, Sir; I'm his Witneſs, it was all Counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I thought I had Reaſons—But it was a poor Contrivance, the Effect has ſhewn it ſuch.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Contrivance, what to cheat me? to cheat your Father! Sirrah, could you hope to proſper?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Indeed, I thought, Sir, when the Father endeavour'd to undo the Son, it was a reaſonable return of Nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Very good, Sir—Mr. Buckram, are you ready?—Come, Sir, will you Sign and Seal?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Sir; but firſt I would ask this Lady one Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Sir, you muſt ask me leave firſt; that Lady, no, Sir; you ſhall ask that Lady no Queſtions, 'till you have ask'd her Bleſſing, Sir; that Lady is to be my Wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I have heard as much, Sir; but I would have it from her own Mouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: That's as much as to ſay I lie, Sir, and you don't believe what I ſay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir. But I reflect that I very lately counterfeited Madneſs; I don't know but the Frolick may go round.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Come, Chuck, ſatisfie him, anſwer him;—Come, come, Mr. Buckram, the Pen and Ink.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Here it is, Sir, with the Deed, all is ready.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: 'Tis true, you have a great while pretended Love to me; nay, what if you were ſincere? Still you muſt Pardon me, if I think my own Inclinations have a better Right to diſpoſe of my Perſon, than yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Are you anſwer'd now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Where's your Plot, Sir? And your Contrivance now, Sir? Will you Sign, Sir? Come, will you Sign and Seal?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, you are not Mad indeed, to ruin your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I have been diſappointed of my only Hope; and he that loſes Hope may part with any thing. I never valu'd Fortune, but as it was ſubſervient to my Pleaſure; and my only Pleaſure was to pleaſe this Lady: I have made many vain Attemps, and find at laſt that nothing but my Ruin can effect it: Which, for that Reaſon, I will Sign to—Give me the Paper.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Generous Valentine!

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Here is the Deed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But where is the Bond, by which I am oblig'd to Sign this?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Sir Sampſon, you have it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No, I have it; and I'll uſe it, as I would every thing that is an Enemy to Valentine.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: How now!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Had I the World to give you, it could not make me worthy of ſo generous and faithful a Paſſion: Here's my Hand, my Heart was always yours, and ſtruggl'd very hard to make this utmoſt Trial of your Virtue. [To Val.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Between Pleaſure and Amazement I am loſt—But on my Knees I take the Bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Oons, what is the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Meſs here's the Wind chang'd again. Father, you and I may make a Voyage together now.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well, Sir Sampſon, ſince I have plaid you a Trick, I'll adviſe you, how you may avoid ſuch another. Learn to be a good Father, or you'll never get a ſecond Wife. I always lov'd your Son, and hated your unforgiving Nature. I was reſolv'd to try him to the utmoſt; I have try'd you too, and know you both. You have not more Faults than he has Virtues; and 'tis hardly more Pleaſure to me, that I can make him and my ſelf happy, than that I can puniſh you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If my Happineſs could receive Addition, this kind Surprize would make it double.

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: Oons you're a Crocodile.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.p: Really, Sir Sampſon, this is a ſudden Eclipſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Samp.
sp.p: You're an illiterate Fool, and I'm another, and the Stars are Liars; and if I had Breath enough, I'd curſe them and you, my ſelf and every Body—Oons, Cully'd, Bubbl'd, Jilted, Woman-bobb'd at laſt, I have not Patience.

sp.speaker: Tatt.
sp.p: If the Gentleman is in this Diſorder for want of a Wife, I can ſpare him mine. Oh, are you there, Sir? I'm indebted to you for my Happineſs. [To Jere.

sp.speaker: Jere.
sp.p: Sir, I ask you Ten Thouſand Pardons, 'twas an errant Miſtake—You ſee, Sir, my Maſter was never mad, nor any thing like it—Then how could it be otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tattle, I thank you; you would have interpoſed between me and Heav'n, but Providence laid Purgatory in your way—You have but Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: I hear the Fiddles that Sir Sampſon provided for his own Wedding; methinks 'tis pity they ſhould not be employ'd when the Match is ſo much mended. Valentine, tho' it be Morning, we may have a Dance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Any thing, my Friend, every thing that looks like Joy and Tranſport.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: Call 'em, Jeremy.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I have done diſſembling now, Valentine; and if that Coldneſs which I have always worn before you, ſhould turn to an extream Fondneſs, you muſt not ſuſpect it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I'll prevent that Suſpicion—For I intend to doat on at that immoderate rate, that your Fondneſs ſhall never diſtinguiſh it ſelf enough to be taken notice of. If ever you ſeem to love too much, it muſt be only when I can't love enough.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Have a care of Promiſes: You know you are apt to run more in Debt than you are able to pay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Therefore I yield my Body as your Priſoner, and make your beſt on't.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: The Muſick ſtays for you.

sp.speaker: Scan.
sp.p: Well, Madam, you have done Exemplary Juſtice, in puniſhing an inhuman Father, and rewarding a faithful Lover: But there is a third good Work, which I, in particular, muſt thank you for; I was an Infidel to your Sex, and you have converted me—For now I am convinc'd that all Women are not like Fortune, blind in beſtowing Favours, either to thoſe who do not merit, or who do not want 'em.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: 'Tis an unreaſonable Accuſation, that you lay upon our Sex: You tax us with Injuſtice, only to cover your own want of Merit. You would all have the Reward of Love, but few have the C •• ſtancy to ſtay 'till it becomes your due. Men are generally Hypocrites and Infidels, they pretend to Worſhip, but have neither Zeal nor Faith: How few, like Valentine, would perſerve even unto Martyrdom, and ſacrifice their Intereſt to their Conſtancy! In admi • ing me, you miſplace the Novelty.
sp.l: The Miracle to Day is, that we find
A Lover true: Not that a Woman's kind.
